intro: Alnus cremastogyne, commonly known as the Chinese alder, is a deciduous tree native to eastern Asia. It belongs to the genus Alnus, which includes species known for their nitrogen-fixing abilities through symbiotic relationships with Frankia bacteria. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has simple, alternate, ovate to lanceolate leaves. Its small, yellowish flowers appear in catkins, and it produces small, fleshy berries that are an important food source for various wildlife. The wood is lightweight and has been used historically for construction and crafts.
